newsitem.title: FRANCE: Paris store employee faked bomb scare - police.
newsitem.headline: Paris store employee faked bomb scare - police.

text.p: A security guard at a Paris clothing store has admitted faking a bomb scare last weekend which he initially blamed on three men of North African origin, a police spokesman said on Friday.
The scare has now been reclassified as a false alarm, one of 441 recorded in the capital since the rush-hour bombing of a Paris commuter train on December 3 in which four people died, police said.
Police did not release the name of the man, who was still being questioned, and it was not yet known if he would be charged with a crime.

The police official said the guard had acknowledged lying when he told authorities that he had come across three men in the store where he worked handling a gas canister, nails and bolts, and had attempted to question them.
The bomb used in the commuter train attack had similar components.
He acknowledged that had even cut himself after initially telling police that the three men had slashed him with a linoleum cutter before making their escape.
A few days later, police found the man tied up in the back seat of his car in a Paris suburb. He said he had been kidnapped at his home by four men who questioned and then threatened him.
But that, too, was a fabrication, police said.
It was unclear why the guard had fabricated the incidents, the official said.
Security has been sharply stepped up in Paris following the train bombing.
Three-quarters of the bomb scares since the train bombing have concerned suspicious packages abandoned or forgotten in public places, the police said.
